comment.author: 21647809@N04
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/27331537@N06] What is the location of this shot, do we know?

comment.author: 35179849@N08
comment._content: Pennant and Palmer Street, isn't it ?    I was just researching one of my dodgy relatives and it happens to be right around the corner from his house.

comment.author: 35179849@N08
comment._content: Actually, thats a good question, because Pennant St does not seem to be self-evident. www.photosau.com.au/CoSMaps/scripts/home.asp Looked at all the maps on there, and I don't see any Pennant Street

comment.author: 35179849@N08
comment._content: The "Echo Red Coupons" sign,  dates the sign to 1925-1927.   Although the photo might be later as the sign does not look brand new.    The car looks like that period also.

comment.author: 35179849@N08
comment._content: S.Gorton and Sons were grocers at the corner of Church and Pennant Street, Parramatta,   and had a chicken farm in Seven Hills Road.    It appears that Pennant Street in Parramatta is not the same one called Pennant Street today.

comment.author: 35179849@N08
comment._content: Now if the west end of Victoria Road was called Pennant St (  not inconceivable,  because Pennant St remains the name of the west end stub of Kissing Pt road ),   and church st was called Palmer St,   then this could be the corner of church and victoria in parramatta.     However,  I rather doubt that Church St was ever called Palmer Street here.

comment.author: 35179849@N08
comment._content: You have the corner of the park on the left of shot,  and a building which looks like the royal oak one block down on the left,    and at the top of the hill,   the junction of the windsor road and the pennant hills road.

comment.author: 35179849@N08
comment._content: And that is where it is ....   Palmer Street is a laneway,  behind the photographer and to his right.    It is Parramatta !

comment.author: 35179849@N08
comment._content: Where that Gorton is,    was a Bunnings for about 20 years,  big new building there now.

comment.author: 35179849@N08
comment._content: Despite the dodgy caption,   the photo is actually looking north along Church street,   and the cross street you can see,   is now Victoria Road.

comment.author: 35179849@N08
comment._content: The tramway from downtown Parramatta to Baulkham hills was opened in 1910.   In 1921,  it was upgraded to a light railway  and the section from Parramatta to Northmead was replaced by a new connection to Westmead station.   So the tram tracks in Church street could have been removed any time after 1921.    But the red coupon sign would date the photo as no earlier than 1925.

comment.author: 35179849@N08
comment._content: So it is nowhere near your wharf, John,  unless you have another wharf that you haven't told us about.
